personas.persona_label: A solo teacher learning to walk again—literally and figuratively. Her week aboard Radiance of the Seas becomes an unexpected lesson in healing and grace.
personas.title: Harper’s Northbound Journey: Learning to Walk Again on Radiance of the Seas
personas.markdown:
## Full disclosure
I have not yet sailed *Radiance of the Seas*. Until I do, this Logbook is an aggregate of vetted guest soundings, taken in their own wake, trimmed and edited to our standards.

## The Crew and Staff
When I stepped aboard in Vancouver, the cast boot around my ankle drew more attention than my smile. I’d sprained it three months earlier—nothing heroic, just a tumble on the school steps after chasing a seventh-grader who’d forgotten his trombone. But for a woman who lives by the bell schedule, being forced to slow down felt like punishment. The crew didn’t see it that way. From the first greeting—“Welcome home, Miss Harper”—to the way the stateroom attendant quietly left an extra ice pack in my mini-fridge, I was reminded that kindness moves faster than pain. One barista learned my order (“half-sweet mocha, extra patience”) by day two. The ship itself seemed to conspire in my healing.

## Embarkation & Disembarkation
Boarding at Canada Place was smoother than my own stride. The pier staff guided me to the accessibility lane, and within twenty minutes I was leaning on the rail, watching seaplanes lift off like prayers over the harbor. Disembarkation in Seward a week later felt harder—not physically, but emotionally. There’s something about the final morning at sea, the slow rotation of the ship into the fjord light, that makes you realize the horizon was never the point. It was learning to look up again.

## The Real Talk
Not every moment was picture-perfect. There were times I caught my reflection in the elevator mirror and hated the limp. The jogging track mocked me. And yes, sometimes the Wi-Fi vanished like motivation on a Monday. But one evening near Hubbard Glacier, I sat alone on Deck 12 as the captain swung us broadside to the ice. The ship fell utterly silent—no announcements, no chatter—just the groan of ancient ice cracking open. A stranger, maybe late sixties, eased into the chair beside me. He didn’t offer a drink; he offered a story. Thirty years married, first cruise since his wife’s chemo ended. He said, “You never realize how loud healing is until you hear it echo.” We sat there in shared quiet until a chunk of ice calved and thundered into the sea. For the first time in months, I didn’t wince at the sound of breaking. I whispered, mostly to myself, “This is what grace sounds like.”

## Accessibility on the Seas
Radiance is one of the easier ships I’ve navigated—wide corridors, elevators at every turn, and crew who don’t treat accessibility like charity. The spa arranged a short-duration massage suited for limited mobility. Even tender ports like Icy Strait Point were managed with thoughtful ramps and steady hands. My favorite detail? Crew members never hovered—they simply appeared when needed, like well-timed commas in a long sentence.

## A Female Crewmate’s Perspective
On day four, a housekeeper named Lila found me sketching glaciers in the Solarium. She sat down on break and said, “We all come to sea for something. Some to run, some to rest.” She told me she sends most of her paycheck home to Cebu and hasn’t seen her children in two years. Then she smiled: “But I still get to watch people heal.” There was no sermon in her words, yet I felt one forming in my chest. Grace again—steady, unspectacular, holy.

## Closing Thoughts
By the time we reached Seward, I no longer cared how fast I walked. I cared that I could stand on my own deck and breathe without rushing the view. Radiance didn’t cure me; it recalibrated me. It taught me that healing isn’t about getting back to normal—it’s about finding beauty in the limp. If you see a woman on the next sailing, camera in one hand and a slow step in the other, say hello. I might just tell you what grace sounds like in glacier light.

Full disclosure: I have not yet sailed Radiance of the Seas. Until I do, this Logbook is an aggregate of vetted guest soundings, taken in their own wake, trimmed and edited to our standards.

## Intro
We picked a **Western Caribbean** itinerary from **Tampa** in **January 2025**: sea day to warm up, then **Cozumel**, **Costa Maya**, and **Roatán**. I told my nine-year-old—soccer-obsessed, picky eater—that this trip could be ours. Radiance felt sized for conversation: generous windows, crew who learned first names, and just enough sparkle to make bedtime a negotiation.

## Small Ship, Big Room for Moments
Day one we found the **sports court** and a sunset pickup game; day two the **poolside movies** bribed us into sitting still. My kid discovered the soft-serve machine; I discovered he’ll try new foods if they follow pizza. Evenings in the **Schooner Bar** meant quiet trivia and a chair that looked out to the kind of dusk you only get at sea.

## Ashore
**Cozumel**: we skipped the jeep tour and did tacos + beach time; the sand turned dad jokes into currency. **Costa Maya**: rented a golf cart in Mahahual and chased pelicans down the malecon. **Roatán**: a reef snorkel where my kid grabbed my hand when a sea turtle drifted by—no words, just the squeeze.

## Budget Notes
Main Dining handled the picky-eater matrix; **Windjammer** covered the rest. I bought the **Refreshment Package** (worth it for fresh juices and sodas). Book shore time privately or walk-up—plenty of safe, simple options.

## Tear-Tug
On the last night he handed me a crumpled napkin list titled “Top 5 Dad + Me.” Number 1 was “laughed until we choked on ice cream.” I kept it. It’s in my wallet now.

Full disclosure: I have not yet sailed Radiance of the Seas. Until I do, this Logbook is an aggregate of vetted guest soundings, taken in their own wake, trimmed and edited to our standards.

## Intro
We chose **southbound Alaska** in **September 2024** (Seward → Vancouver): **Hubbard Glacier**, **Skagway**, **Juneau**, **Icy Strait Point**, **Ketchikan**, then the quiet slide home through the **Inside Passage**. It was Mom’s dream; mine was to keep up.

## The Rhythm We Needed
Radiance’s **solarium** felt built for tenderness: warm air, soft light, crew who lowered their voices without being asked. In **Skagway**, we did the **White Pass** train—she pressed her palm to the glass at the trestle and whispered, “Imagine building that.” In **Juneau**, we watched a whale sound and vanish like a shared secret.

## Dining & Ease
We alternated **Main Dining** with **Chops Grille** (she called the filet “Sunday best”). Elevators were close, theater aisles forgiving. I pushed the pace only once and learned my lesson.

## Tear-Tug
At **Ketchikan**, rain stitched the docks into a watercolor. Mom slipped her arm into mine and said, “Your dad would have teased this weather and loved it anyway.” We laughed and stood there in it. A crew member handed us towels with a grin like family.

## Intro
I grabbed a shoulder-season **northbound** in **early June 2024** (Vancouver → Seward), praying for whales and workable Wi-Fi. The ship felt like a greenhouse set to awe—glass everywhere, mountains everywhere else.

## The Hunt
At **Icy Strait Point**, I learned patience is half the shot: five minutes watching water, then the sudden breath and plume. **Hubbard Glacier** calved like a drumline. Onboard, the **Viking Crown Lounge** made a perfect editing bay between sunlight and sockets.

## Food & Frugal
**Windjammer** breakfasts, **Main Dining** dinners; I splurged once at **Giovanni’s** and lingered too long over espresso. Crew slipped me ship-side ginger tea when I looked green returning from a skiff—love them for that.

## Tear-Tug
A woman on deck asked if I ever put the camera down. I said I try. We watched a seal ride a floe like a couch and I didn’t take the shot. It was better that way.

**Juneau**: helicopter canceled; we pivoted to a walk to **Mendenhall Glacier** and ended up loving the blue in the lake ice. **Ketchikan**: rain on cedar, hand-in-hand on **Creek Street**.

## Intro
We booked **Vancouver round-trip** in **August 2024**—a classic loop: **Ketchikan**, **Icy Strait Point**, **Juneau**, scenic **Endicott Arm/Dawes Glacier** (schedule shift from Hubbard that week), and home via the **Inside Passage**. Radiance gave us glass, greenery, and time.

## The Plan
Mornings in **Windjammer** near the aft windows (wheelchair-friendly layout), afternoons swapping **kids’ club** and **solarium** time, evenings in **Main Dining** where servers turned the lemon tart into theater.

## Ashore
**Juneau**: whale-watch + Mendenhall lookout—gentle walking, giant payoff. **Icy Strait Point**: boardwalk ease, bonfire scent, and an eagle that seemed hired.

## Tear-Tug
Nana whispered grace over salmon chowder while mountains slid by. My teen—who rolls eyes for sport—said “Amen” like a reflex. I blinked fast and blamed the wind.

We sailed **southbound** in **June 2025** (Seward → Vancouver). Ports: **Hubbard Glacier**, **Skagway**, **Juneau**, **Icy Strait Point**, **Ketchikan**. Homework was banned, curiosity wasn’t.

## Shipboard Classroom
The **Observation areas** turned into labs: cloud types, tidal notes, gull IDs. Crew taught the kids napkin-folding and kindness; both stuck.

## Ashore
**Juneau**: a whale-watch where my son gasped loud enough for the boat to laugh. **Skagway**: stories of the **Klondike** and a lesson in why people chase hard things. **Ketchikan**: totems and rain that made its own music.

## Tear-Tug
At **Hubbard**, my daughter asked if ice can be alive. I said not like us, but it moves and sings and changes. She tucked her hand in mine and we listened.

A **Western Caribbean** itinerary from **Tampa** in **February 2024**: sea day → **Belize City** → **Roatán** → **Cozumel** → sea day. I brought travel brushes and left the to-do list at home.

**Solarium** light for sketching, **Schooner Bar** for live piano and people studies, **Main Dining** for meals that arrived like punctuation marks.
